petrochemical industry. The story of oil is

Parts of that story are well-known: Rockefeller

engine and the transformation of global transport;
the House of Saud and the oil wars in the

Other parts are more obscure: the quest for
oil and the outbreak of World War I; the petrochemical

74.text:
interests behind modern medicine; the Big
Oil money behind the “Green Revolution”

80.text:
But that story, properly told, begins somewhere
unexpected. Not in Pennsylvania with the first

87.text:
commercial drilling operation and the first
oil boom, but in the rural backwoods of early

92.text:
19th century New York state. And it doesn’t
start with crude oil or its derivatives, but

97.text: a different product altogether: snake oil.

101.text:
“Dr. Bill Livingston, Celebrated Cancer
Specialist” was the very image of the traveling

106.text:
snake oil salesman. He was neither a doctor,
nor a cancer specialist; his real name was

112.text:
not even Livingston. More to the point, the
“Rock Oil” tonic he pawned was a useless

117.text:
mixture of laxative and petroleum and had
no effect whatsoever on the cancer of the

121.text: poor townsfolk he conned into buying it.

124.text:
He lived the life of a vagabond, always on
the run from the last group of people he had

128.text:
fooled, engaged in ever more outrageous deceptions
to make sure that the past wouldn’t catch

133.text:
up with him. He abandoned his first wife and
their six children to start a bigamous marriage

137.text:
in Canada at the same time as he fathered
two more children by a third woman. He adopted

143.text:
the name “Livingston” after he was indicted
for raping a girl in Cayuga in 1849.

149.text:
When he wasn’t running away from them or
disappearing for years at a time, he would

152.text:
teach his children the tricks of his treacherous
trade. He once bragged of his parenting technique:

158.text:
“I cheat my boys every chance I get. I want
to make ’em sharp.”

163.text:
A towering man of over six feet and with natural
good looks that he used to his advantage,

168.text:
he went by “Big Bill.” Others, less generously,
called him “Devil Bill.” But his real

173.text:
name was William Avery Rockefeller, and it
was his son, John D. Rockefeller, who would

179.text:
go on to found the Standard Oil monopoly and
become the world’s first billionaire.

184.text:
The world we live in today is the world created
in “Devil” Bill’s image. It’s a world

189.text:
founded on treachery, deceit, and the naivety
of a public that has never wised up to the

193.text:
parlor tricks that the Rockefellers and their
ilk have been using to shape the world for

197.text: the past century and a half.

200.text: This is the story of the oiligarchy.

206.text: PART ONE: BIRTH OF THE OIL-IGARCHY

222.text:
Titusville, 1857. A most unlikely man alights
from a railway car into the midst of this

227.text:
sleepy Western Pennsylvania town on the shores
of Oil Creek: “Colonel” Edwin Drake. He’s

233.text:
from the Pennsylvania Rock Oil Company, and
he’s here on a mission: to collect oil.

239.text:
Like “Dr.” Bill, Drake isn’t really
a Colonel. The title is bestowed on him by

244.text:
George Bissell and James Townsend, a lawyer
and a banker who started the Pennsylvania

248.text:
Rock Oil Company after they discovered they
could distill the region’s naturally occurring

252.text:
Seneca oil into lamp oil, or kerosene. Drake
is actually an unemployed railroad conductor

258.text:
who talked himself into a job after staying
at the same hotel as Bissel the year before.

264.text:
Calling him a Colonel, it is hoped, will help
win the respect of the locals.

269.text:
The locals think he’s crazy anyway. Seneca
oil is indeed plentiful, bubbling out of seeps

274.text:
and collecting in the creek, but other than
as a cure-all medicine or grease for the local

278.text:
sawmill’s machinery, it’s hardly seen
as something valuable. In fact, it can be

283.text:
a downright nuisance, contaminating brine
wells that supply Pittsburgh’s booming salt

289.text:
Still, Drake has a task to complete: finding
a way to collect enough oil to make the distillation

295.text:
of Seneca oil into lamp oil profitable. He
tries everything he can think of. The Native

301.text:
Americans had historically collected the oil
by damming the creek near a seep and skimming

305.text:
the oil off the top. But Drake can only collect
six to ten gallons of oil a day this way,

311.text:
even when he opens up extra seeps. He tries
digging a shaft, but the groundwater floods

318.text:
By the summer of 1859 he’s desperate. Drake’s
running out of ideas, Bissell and Townsend

323.text:
are running out of patience and, most importantly,
the company is running out of funds. He turns

329.text:
to “Uncle” Billy Smith, a Pittsburgh blacksmith
who had experience drilling brine wells with

334.text:
steam-powered equipment. They get to work
drilling down through the shale bedrock to

338.text:
reach the oil. It’s maddeningly slow work,
with the crude equipment struggling to get

343.text:
through three feet of bedrock a day. By August
27th they’ve drilled down 69 and a half

349.text:
feet, Drake has used the last of his funds,
and Bissell and his partners have decided

353.text:
to close up the operation. On August 28th,
they strike oil.

360.text:
Narrator: Then on Sunday, August 28th, 1859,
oil bubbled up the drive pipe. Uncle Billy

372.text:
and his son Sam bailed out several buckets
of oil. On Monday, the very day that Colonel

382.text:
Drake received his final payment and an order
to close down the operation, they hitched

386.text:
the walking beam to a water pump and the oil
began to flow. The first oil was to sell for

393.text:
$40 a barrel. Years later a local newspaper
interviewed Uncle Billy about the day they

400.text:
“I commenced drilling and at 4:00 I struck
the oil. I says to Mr. Drake, ‘Look there!

406.text:
What do you think of this?’ He looked down
the pipe and said, ‘What’s that?’ And

417.text:
Drake’s well proved that by drilling for
it, oil could be found in abundance and produced

428.text:
cheaply. Overnight a whole new industry was
born. Before long in millions of homes, farms

440.text:
and factories around the world, lamps would
be lit with kerosene refined from West Pennsylvania

447.text:
Daniel Yergin: When the word came out that
Drake had struck oil, the cry went up throughout

451.text:
the narrow valleys of Western Pennsylvania:
‘The crazy Yankee has struck oil! The crazy

455.text:
Yankee has struck oil!’ And it was the first
great boom. It was like a gold rush.

474.text:
Overnight the quiet farming backwoods of rural
Pennsylvania was transformed into a bustling

478.text:
oil region, with prospectors leasing up flats,
towns springing up from nowhere, and a forest

483.text:
of percussion rigs covering the land. The
first oil boom had arrived.

489.text:
Already poised to make the most of this boom
was a young up-and-coming bookkeeper in Cleveland

493.text:
with a head for numbers: John Davison Rockefeller.
He had two ambitions in life: to make $100,000

502.text:
and to live to 100 years old. John D. set
off to make his fortune in the late 1850s,

508.text:
armed with a $1000 loan from his father, “Devil”
Bill.

512.text:
David Rockefeller: Grandfather never finished
high school and went to Cleveland having borrowed

518.text:
$1000 from his father to start a business
— paid 9% interest on it incidentally. And

526.text:
he read about the oil business just beginning
and got interested, and came to realize it

533.text: was a very volatile business at the time.

540.text:
In 1863, seeing the oil boom and sensing the
profits to be made in the fledgling business,

545.text:
Rockefeller formed a partnership with fellow
businessman Maurice B. Clark and Samuel Andrews,

550.text:
a chemist who had built an oil refinery but
knew little about the business of getting

553.text:
his product to market. In 1865 the shrewd
John D. bought out his partners for $72,500

560.text:
and, with Andrews as partner, launched Rockefeller
& Andrews. By 1870, after five years of strategic

567.text:
partnerships and mergers, Rockefeller had
incorporated Standard Oil.

573.text:
The story of the rise of Standard Oil is an
oft-told one.

576.text:
Narrator: In a move that would transform the
American economy, Rockefeller set out to replace

583.text:
a world of independent oilmen with a giant
company controlled by him. In 1870, begging

594.text:
bankers for more loans, he formed Standard
Oil of Ohio. The next year, he quietly put

602.text:
what he called “our plan” — his campaign
to dominate the volatile oil industry — into

609.text:
devastating effect. Rockefeller knew that
the refiner with the lowest transportation

617.text:
cost could bring rivals to their knees. He
entered into a secret alliance with the railroads

625.text:
called the South Improvement Company. In exchange
for large, regular shipments, Rockefeller

631.text:
and his allies secured transport rates far
lower than those of their bewildered competitors.

633.text:
Ida Tarbell, the daughter of an oil man, later
remembered how men like her father struggled

635.text:

began running up and down the Oil Regions,”

637.text:
Improvement Company — a company unheard

639.text:

lip there was but one word and that was ‘conspiracy.'”

642.text:
Ron Chernow, Biographer: By 1879, when Rockefeller

644.text:
in the world. Within a few years, he will

649.text:

671.text:

679.text:

703.text:

713.text:
In 1891, the Rothschilds contracted with M.

729.text:

733.text:

739.text:
If word of the endeavour was to get back to

752.text:

758.text:
In 1897 “M. Samuel & Co.” became The Shell

reliance on the Rothschild/Nobel Caspian oil

769.text:

774.text:
Royal Dutch Petroleum, established in The

778.text:

784.text:

Another global competitor to the Standard

the 20th century. In 1901 millionaire socialite

810.text:

they sent a telegram to their geologist telling

But it was not just about money. The monopolization

century, helped secure the oiligarchs not

Billions who came to depend on black gold

940.text:

953.text:

966.text:
By the dawn of the 20th century electric cars
accounted for 28% of the automobiles in the

971.text:
United States. The electrics had advantages
over the internal combustion engine: they

976.text:
required no gear shifting or hand cranking,

providing cheap, plentiful oil to the American

long before the expensive, low range electric

1005.text:
loud, gas-guzzling engines came to dominate

Rockefeller had come under increasing scrutiny

wealth he had amassed through Standard Oil.
Muckraking reporters like Ida Tarbell began

digging up the dirt on his rise to power through

and other shady practices. The press pictured
him as a colossus with bribed politicians

1042.text:
literally in the palm of his hand; Standard

strangling the lifeblood of the nation. Hearings

were brought against him. And then, finally,
in 1911 the Supreme Court made a monumental

the decision while golfing at Kykuit with

So that Standard Oil was punished in the federal

For the oiligarchy, the lesson of the rise

1214.text: PART TWO: COMPETITION IS A SIN

1227.text:
When asked how he could justify the treachery
and deceit with which he pursued the creation

1231.text:
of the Standard Oil monopoly, John D. Rockefeller
is reputed to have said: “Competition is

1237.text:
a sin.” This is the mentality of the monopolist,
and it is this justification, framed as religious

1244.text:
conviction, that drove the oiligarchs to so
ruthlessly eliminate anyone who would dare

1248.text: rise up as a pretender to their throne.

1251.text:
Ironically, it was the competition between
the oiligarchs in the early 20th century that

1256.text:
helped give rise to an early external threat
to their empire: alcohol fuel.

1262.text:
As historian Lyle Cummins has noted of the
period: “The oil trust battles between Rockefeller,

1267.text:
the Rothschilds, the Nobels and Marcus Samuel’s
Shell kept prices in a state of flux, and

1273.text:
engines often had to be adaptable to the fuel
that was available.”

1277.text:
In many areas where oil wasn’t available,
the alternative was alcohol. Ethyl alcohol

1283.text:
had been used as a fuel for lamps and engines
since the early 19th century. Although it

1287.text:
was generally more expensive, alcohol fuel
offered a stability of supply that was alluring,

1292.text:
especially in areas like London or Paris that
did not have predictable access to oil supplies.

1298.text:
Alcohol has a lower heat value, or BTU, than
gasoline, but a series of tests by the US

1303.text:
Geological Survey and the US Navy in 1907
and 1908 proved that the higher compression

1308.text:
ratio of alcohol engines could perfectly offset
the lower heat value, thus making alcohol

1313.text: and gasoline engines fuel economy equivalent.

1317.text:
One early supporter of alcohol fuel was Henry
Ford, who designed his Model T to run on either

1322.text:
alcohol or gasoline. Sensing an opportunity
for new markets to boost the independent American

1328.text:
farms that he felt were vital to the nation,
Henry Ford told the New York Times:

1332.text:
“The fuel of the future is going to come
from fruit like that sumach out by the road,

1336.text:
or from apples, weeds, sawdust – almost
anything. There is fuel in every bit of vegetable

1343.text:
Farmers, looking to capitalize on this, lobbied

1351.text:

1355.text:

monopoly. In support of a bill to repeal the

1361.text:

the US Congress in 1906:

1366.text:

unfair or unlawful methods, crushed out home

1372.text:
competition. It is highly desirable that an
element of competition should be introduced

1376.text:
by the passage of some such law as that which
has already passed the House, putting alcohol

1381.text:

free list.”

1386.text:
The alcohol tax was repealed in 1906 and for

The promise of cheap, unpatentable, unmonopolizable

For the oiligarchs, the answer was simple:

1429.text:
alcohol engines. Thankfully for them, the

1437.text:
In the 19th century, America had a drinking

15 years old drank seven gallons of pure alcohol

1449.text:
average. This led to the first anti-alcohol

1454.text:
formation of the Prohibition Party in 1869
and the Women’s Christian Temperance Union

1458.text:
in the 1870s. The movement enjoyed widespread
and growing support but had few political

1465.text:
successes; Maine flirted with prohibition

1469.text: in 1851, but the ban only lasted five years.

1474.text:
This changed with the formation of the Anti-Saloon
League in Standard Oil’s birth state of

1477.text:
Ohio in 1893. The ASL was started by John
D. Rockefeller’s long-time personal friend

1484.text:
Howard Hyde Russell and was bankrolled in

1488.text:
himself. The ASL, with Rockefeller’s backing,

1494.text:
national movement to outlaw the production
and sale of alcohol.

1499.text:
Rockefeller was a teetotaler himself, not

1503.text:
that “good cheer among friends” would
lead to his downfall in business. Stephen

1508.text:
Harkness, one of the silent partner investors

1512.text:
until his death, had caught Rockefeller’s

1516.text:
in advance of a new excise tax that he had

1522.text:
No, Rockefeller and Standard Oil were not

1529.text:
as far as it impacted their bottom line. But

1535.text:

1540.text:
it did lead to increasingly burdensome restrictions

1545.text:

1551.text:

Another existential threat to the vast fortunes

1561.text:

1567.text:
By the end of World War I, private car ownership

Americans owned a car. Rail was still the
transportation of choice for the vast majority

1576.text:
of the public, and city-dwellers in most major

to transport them around town. In 1936, General
